reasoning: The critique targets an alleged tension between (i) the essay’s “narrow target/no easy eutopia” framing and (ii) an illustrative trade example involving “common-sense utopia.” This is somewhat central insofar as the essay uses that example to motivate moral trade optimism, but it’s not a linchpin of the main argument (which is about convergence vs partial convergence+trade under uncertainty). The critique is weak because it largely relies on a misread: the essay does not assume common-sense morality is correct; it says common-sense utopia achieves most value *by common-sense lights*, which can be true even if common-sense is far from the “correct” view. Trade scenarios can be valuable (to common-sense agents) without implying the target is wide or that convergence is likely. Still, the conditional point (“if common-sense morality were correct, the target would be less narrow for many”) is coherent, giving it moderate correctness. It’s clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little fluff.
title: Common-sense morality cannot be both reliable enough for trade and unreliable enough for non-convergence
